timeline.bodyText: Use Collections.newSetFromMap(new ConcurrentHashMap<String,Boolean>()) instead. Then we can remove the synchronised in the add and remove methods bellow.
timeline.author: chrisvest

replies.bodyText: At first I thought maybe it would be used elsewhere.
replies.author: wuxiansen

timeline.bodyText: I don't think there's any exception that can happen here?
timeline.author: chrisvest

replies.bodyText:
Maybe it is redundant，If an unknown problem occurs with add and remove, I just want to make sure that it will not affect the normal process.
Or am I thinking a little too much?
replies.author: wuxiansen

replies.bodyText: Yeah, they're just methods on Set. They can only throw Errors or RuntimeExceptions, and I think we should just let those bubble out if they ever happen.
replies.author: chrisvest

timeline.bodyText: With a Set based on ConcurrentHashMap, we can just iterate it directly. Since we are at JVM shut down at this point, I don't think we need to clear the set.
timeline.author: chrisvest

timeline.bodyText: Remove comment.
timeline.author: chrisvest

timeline.bodyText: Easier to do the casts at variable declaration site.

timeline.bodyText: What behaviour are we trying to verify?
timeline.author: chrisvest

timeline.bodyText: Remove comment.
timeline.author: chrisvest

timeline.bodyText: Why is the length zero when we set 4 bytes of content?
timeline.author: chrisvest

replies.bodyText: Throw an exception to test whether the hook will execute properly at the end of the program.
replies.author: wuxiansen

timeline.bodyText: Remove comment. Also, we should verify that the file no longer exists, and that it's pathname is no longer in the set of files to delete on shut down.
timeline.author: chrisvest

timeline.bodyText: We should also have a test that verifies that the registered files are deleted by the shut down hook.
